facts.text: The land in suit, area of a little over 9 acres, was property of Basappa who died before 1918 leaving three daughters: Paramma, Pompamma, Hampamma.
Under settlement deeds Exhibits P-2 and P-3 (1918 and 1919), three sisters got 15-16 acres wet land in absolute right. Hampamma took her one-third share.
Paramma and Pompamma enjoyed remaining two-thirds share (9 acres 49 cents wet land), subject of suit.
Pompamma married Nagana Gowd, gave birth to two sons Siddalingana and Chenabasavana, died in 1923. Her share devolved on two sons.
After Pompamma's death, Nagana remarried and stayed in ancestral village; two infant sons remained with Paramma (mother's sister) who reared them.
On 22nd June 1923, Paramma executed deed of gift conveying her share in suit property to two sons of Pompamma. They got entirety of 9 acres 49 cents jointly.
Siddalingana (elder son) died in 1924. Plaintiff's case: his half-share devolved on father Nagana under Hindu law.
Paramma continued to possess entirety on behalf of younger son Chenabasavana (defendant No. 1).
On 25th August 1926, lease deed Exhibit D-1 and counterpart D-2: Paramma leased entire property from Nagana as guardian of infant Chenabasavana for 12 years at Rs. 500/year.
Rent receipts by Nagana to Paramma on behalf of Chenabasavana: Exhibits D-4 (1927), D-4-1 (1932).

In 1934, Nagana as guardian sued Paramma in Munsif's Court Hospet for Rs. 500 rent; decreed ex parte, discharged by Exhibit D-3 (14th Nov 1934) reciting rents paid as Paramma borrowed for minor's lands.

Nagana became financially involved; on 27th Aug 1935, mortgaged half-share of disputed land by conditional sale to defendant No. 2 for Rs. 3000, reciting it devolved on him on Siddalingana's death and he was in possession.
On 16th July 1936, Nagana sold mortgaged property (Exhibit P-6) to defendant No. 2 for Rs. 3000.
Purchaser (defendant No. 2) did not obtain possession.
On 2nd May 1944, defendant No. 2 sold property to plaintiff (Exhibit P-1).
Plaintiff filed Original Suit No. 17 of 1944 on 18th July 1944 in District Judge Bellary for half-share after partition with defendant No. 1; defendant No. 2 impleaded.
Trial Judge dismissed suit on 23rd July 1945: gift made joint tenants with survivorship; no right to Nagana; suit barred by adverse possession; Nagana disclaimed rights.

Plaintiff appealed to Madras High Court (Appeal No. 654 of 1945); Division Bench (Rajamannar C.J., Balakrishna Ayyar J.) allowed appeal on 28th March 1949: tenants-in-common, not joint; no adverse possession after 1935 mortgage.
Defendant No. 1 appealed to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133 Constitution r/w Ss.109,110 CPC.

legal_issues.text: Whether the two sons took property as joint tenants with survivorship or tenants-in-common, so Siddalingana's interest devolved on brother Chenabasavana or father Nagana.
Whether defendant No. 1 acquired title by adverse possession against Nagana/plaintiff, given lease acts, mortgage, and possession.

petitioner_arguments.text: Deed of gift by Paramma made donees (two brothers) joint tenants with survivorship; Siddalingana's interest devolved on defendant No. 1, not father Nagana.
Plaintiff's suit barred; never in possession; defendant No. 1 acquired title by adverse possession.
Nagana disclaimed rights as co-owner by lease deed, receipts; acted only as guardian of Chenabasavana; presumption of one co-owner's possession for all does not apply.

respondent_arguments.text: Siddalingana's half-share devolved on father Nagana under Hindu law of inheritance.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant not pressing joint tenancy argument; thus after Siddalingana's death, Nagana co-owner with minor son Chenabasavana. Plaintiff derives title from Nagana as co-owner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nagana became co-owner with defendant No. 1.

court_reasoning.text: Presumption: possession of one co-owner on behalf of other unless ouster proved. Defendant No. 1 must prove adverse possession for statutory period.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Peculiarity: father guardian of infant son.

court_reasoning.text: Nagana's lease (1926) as guardian asserted son's exclusive title, denying own; possession of lessee Paramma = possession of infant alone, adverse to father with his consent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Adverse possession possible with consent of true owner.

court_reasoning.text: Nagana's 1935 mortgage asserting own right did not interrupt adverse possession: no re-entry, no resumption of possession, no acknowledgment by minor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere assertion of title by dispossessed co-sharer insufficient without change in possession.

court_reasoning.text: Rent receipts (1927,1932), rent suit (1934), discharge (D-3) all by Nagana as guardian; no claim to rents by him; minor in possession throughout.
Father's acts qua guardian = son's acts; 1935 mortgage personal act of father as proprietor, adverse to son; no effect on son's adverse possession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mental act unaccompanied by possession change ineffective.

holdings.text: After Siddalingana's death, Nagana co-owner, but defendant No. 1 acquired title by adverse possession starting 1926 via lease, uninterrupted by 1935 mortgage.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal read with Constitution

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and decree of High Court set aside; those of District Judge restored; plaintiff's suit dismissed.

key_quotes.text: In law the possession of the lessee is the possession of the lessor and consequently ever since 1926 when Paramma began to possess the property as a lessee... her possession in law was the possession of the infant alone to the exclusion of Nagana.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Once it is held that the possession of a co-sharer has become adverse... the mere assertion of his joint title by the dispossessed co-sharer would not interrupt the running of adverse possession.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on interruption of adverse possession

key_quotes.text: A mere mental act on the part of the person dispossessed unaccompanied by any change of possession cannot affect the continuity of adverse possession of the disseizor.
key_quotes.speaker: court
